title-group.article-title: Does Learning the Principles of Finance Overcome Predictable Irrationality?

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright 2017 by the Journal of Financial Education

abstract.p: The behavioral finance literature suggests that rationality is not a natural thought process and that biases and heuristics lead to predictably irrational choices. In this paper, we test whether learned rationality transfers to rational personal choices. We use a fixed effect approach based on matching responses on survey questions adapted from the behavioral finance literature to exam answers on rational decision principles. Specifically, we test whether learning the rationality principles of opportunity cost, incremental analysis, and time value of money attenuate mental accounting, representativeness, and recent event biases documented in the literature. Our findings support the notion that learning rational decision concepts in the classroom does not necessarily lead to rational decisions in behavioral choice. Behavioral biases are as likely for students with an understanding of the relevant rationality principle as for students without understanding.
